KINETIC THEORY OF MATTER AND GAS LAWS

An ideal gas law or perfect gas are Boyle’s Charles’, Graham’s, Avogadro’s law etc.

Ideal gas laws are obeyed at high temperature and low pressure, and deviation occurs at low temperature and high pressure. When it is disobeyed the gas is no more ideal gas but real gas.

Ideal Gas equation is given as 

PV = nRT

n = number of moles = 

PV =  RT

PM = Density  RT

P= pressure, M = molar mass, R = gas constant = 0.082atmdm3/mol/K = 8.313J/mol/K

 

Boyle’s Law: this relates the pressure and volume of a gas. Boyle’s law states that the pressure of a fixed mass of gas is inversely proportional to its volume provided the temperature is constant 

P  hence PV = constant

M: The value of the constant depends on the mass of gas and the temperature 

P1V1 = P2V2. 

 

Charle’s law: Charles law shows the connection between the volume change with temperature of a fixed mass of gas at constant pressure 

 V  T; V = kT

 

General gas equation: The ideal gas equation is the general relationship between pressure, Volume and temperature of a given mass of gas.

A certain volume of a gas at 298K is heated such that its volume and pressure are now four times the original values. What is the new temperature?

Using the general gas equation

 

V1 = V1; T1 = 298K; P1 = P1; V2 = 4V1; T2 =? P2 = 4P1.

Substituting the values, we have 

 = 

 = 

Cross multiply 

T2   = 298  16P1  V1

Divide by P1  V1 

T2 = 298  16 = 4768.

 

Kinetic theory of gases

The gas molecules move randomly in straight lines, colliding with one another and with the walls of the container. These collisions constitute the gas pressure. 

The pressure is as a result of two factors 

(1) Molecular collision 

(2) Molecular collision with the walls of the container. 

But molecular collision is always neglected because the pressure mainly results from the molecular collision with the walls of the container.

An increase in temperature leads to an increase in the kinetic energy of the gas particles, an increase in the frequency (or number) of collisions and an increase pressure.

The temperature of the gas is proportional to the average kinetic energy of its molecules. Faster moving particles will collide with the container walls more frequently and with greater force. This causes the force on the walls of the container to increase and so the pressure increases.

Average intermolecular distance decreases when a given mass of gas is compressed relative to its initial volume leading to increase in the frequency of collision.

Example 

An increase in temperature causes an increase in the pressure of a gas because there is an increase in the

A. average velocity of the gas molecules, B. number of collisions between the gas molecules, C. density of the gas. Molecules, D. free mean path between each molecule and the other.

B (2010/2011, no 3)

The temperature of the gas is proportional to the average kinetic energy of its molecules. Faster moving particles will collide with the container walls more frequently and with greater force. This causes the force on the walls of the container to increase and so the pressure increases.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

PATIAL PRESSURE

The law of partial pressure states that if there is a mixture of gases which do not react chemically together, then the total pressure exerted by the mixture is the sum of the partial pressures of the individual gases that make up the mixture. Mathematically, this can be expressed as: 

PT = PA + PB + PC + PD +…

Where PT = total pressure of the mixture, and PA, PB, PC, are the partial pressures exerted separately by the individual gases A, B, C that make up the mixture: 

The partial pressure pressure of gas A is given by 

PA = 

Where nA = number of moles of A, while nT = total number of moles.

The partial pressure of N2 in a container at 50℃ in which there are 0.30 mole of N2 and 1.2 mole of CO2 at a pressure of 2.00 atm is?

A. 0.6 atm B. 0.5 atm C. 0.4 atm D. 1.6 atm

B 0.5 atm

RATE OF DIFFUSION

The rate of diffusion of gases are inversely related to their molecular masses. This means that substances with high molecular masses diffuses slowly. 

SO2 has the high molecular mass of (32 + (16  2) = 64), while H2S is the faster because it has the least molecular formular of (2 + 32 = 34).

Example

If the rate of diffusion of oxygen is taken as 1 cm3s-1, what will be the rate of diffusion of methane who relative molecular mass is 16?

A.2.0 B. 1.8 C. 1.4 D. 1.0 (2005/2006, No 5) C.

Extra points to note

Gasification means a process that converts organic/fossil fuel-based carbonaceous materials into carbon monoxide, hydrogen and carbon dioxide.

Synthesis gas, composed principally of carbon monoxide and hydrogen, and are used as the major building block in the production of chemicals and fuels. It is prepared by reacting coke with air and/or steam. There are two types of synthesis gas, Producer gas is produced when air is used in the gasification of coke while water gas is produced when water is used in gasification of coke. 

Producer gas (Air gas) is a combustible mixture of nitrogen, carbon monoxide and hydrogen. It is used as a fuel and prepared by passing air with steam over burning coke or coal in a furnace.

The producer gas is a mixture of CO (from coke) and N2 (from the air).
